name: MOLECULAR IMAGING

values.comments:
This course provides a comprehensive survey of modern medical imaging
modalities with an emphasis on the emerging field of molecular imaging. The basic
principles of X-ray, computed tomography, nuclear imaging, magnetic resonance
imaging, and optical tomography are reviewed. The emphasis of the course, however,
focuses on the concept of contrast media and targeted molecular imaging. Topics
covered include the chemistry and mechanisms of various contrast agents, approaches to
identifying molecular markers of disease, ligand screening strategies, and the basic
principles of toxicology and pharmacology relevant to imaging agents.
Students overall thought this class was interesting, difficult, and rewarding.
Students enjoyed how this course combined bioengineering and medicine. As one
student put it, “This course provided a very good introduction to the different medical
imaging modalities. The course is split into four different modules about four major
medical imaging technologies, each covered a homework assignment and an exam. The
majority of students reported learning a great deal from this course as long as you worked
hard and paid attention in lecture.
Dr. Tsourkas organizes the course around a series of guest lecturers who explain
each individual radiological modality covered in the course. Students enjoyed most guest
lecturers but were occasionally discouraged by poor English ability or poor presentation
style on the guest lecturers’ part. Students said the material taught in this class was
highly theoretical and that they would have appreciated demonstrations of the technology
taught in the class. Dr. Tsourkas teaches his material primarily with PowerPoints that
almost serve as the textbook that students need to reference for the class. Students
complained about the blanks in Dr. Tsourkas PowerPoints, which were intended to
encourage students to come to class, but instead took up students time and concentration
with the fast pace of the course and the difficulty typing all the necessary comments in
the blanks especially the frequent dense mathematics. Students recommended printing
the PowerPoints to make it easier to fill in the blanks and pay attention in class.
Although Dr. Tsourkas mostly read off PowerPoints, students commended his knowledge
of the material, “He is able to add a substantial amount of content to each lecture simply
because of his vast knowledge of the subject matter.” Students complained about the
lack of clear office hours, with no set office hours in the beginning of the semester and
sometimes weeks with only an hour of office hours.
This class is intended for seniors and graduate students in the bioengineering
department. The major difference about taking this course at the graduate level was that
student presentations were required from the graduate students. Students found this
course to be challenging but rewarding. Students enjoyed the consistency with four HW
assignments and four exams on four major different imaging techniques. Students
reported taking four challenging exams during this course, where there was “Almost too
much emphasis on memorization and not enough on understanding major concepts.” The
homework was reported as “tough but fair.”
